Equally Likely Outcomes

Outcome $\omega \in \Omega$
Event $A \subseteq \Omega$ (e.g. $\emptyset, \omega, \Omega$)

Assumptions (1.1):
$\mid \Omega \mid = n \in \mathbb{N}$
$\forall \omega \in \Omega, \Pr(\omega) = \frac{1}{n}$

Conclusion:
Then $\Pr(A \subseteq \Omega) = \frac{\mid A \mid}{\mid \Omega \mid}$: this requires good counting!

Dilemma: When to add, when to multiply

Complementation: $A^C = \bar{A}$
$\mid A^C \mid = \mid \Omega \mid - \mid A \mid \iff \mid A \mid = \mid \Omega \mid - \mid A^C \mid$

Birthday Problem
365 possible birthdays, 50 students
Let $A = \{$ at least 2 students have the same birthday $\}$. Find $\Pr(A)$
Calculate $\Pr(A^C)$; then $\Pr(A) = 1 - \Pr(A^C)$
Now note that our outcome space $\Omega$ has cardinality $365^{50}$ (since each event can be represented as a 50-tuple). We are interested in a subset of this, $A^C$; namely, the tuples having no repeated elements. This subset is counted by $\binom{365}{50}50!$ (Why? First we choose the 50 slots, then we must arrange them in some order).
So, $\Pr(A) = 1 - \frac{\binom{365}{50}50!}{365^{50}}$
